title_en: Founds Mathematical Astronomy & the Method of Exhaustion

summary.text_en: Eudoxus was the most brilliant mathematician and astronomer at Plato's Academy. He solved two major crises: 1. In astronomy, he created the first mathematical model of the cosmos (the 'Homocentric Spheres'), using 27 nested spheres to explain planetary retrograde motion. 2. In mathematics, he invented the 'Method of Exhaustion' (a precursor to calculus) to find areas and volumes of curves, and his 'Theory of Proportions' resolved the crisis caused by the discovery of irrational numbers (like âˆš2).
key_points_en: Homocentric Spheres: The first mathematical model of astronomy
Method of Exhaustion: A precursor to Integral Calculus
Theory of Proportions: Solved the irrational number crisis
Proved a cone's volume is 1/3 that of its corresponding cylinder

story.text_en: When the Pythagoreans found âˆš2 could not be a ratio of integers, Greek mathematics collapsed. Eudoxus's 'Theory of Proportions' (later Book V of Euclid's Elements) saved it. He bypassed 'numbers' and redefined 'ratio'. He argued that two ratios (a/b and c/d) are equal *not* if their values are equal, but if they behave *identically* when compared to all other integer ratios. This allowed mathematicians to rigorously compare rational and irrational ratios, providing a solid logical foundation for geometry.

fun_facts.text_en: His 'Method of Exhaustion' is the origin of the modern calculus concept of a 'limit'. He proved the area of a circle is proportional to its radius squared by inscribing polygons with more and more sides, until the polygon 'exhausted' the area of the circle.

Although Eudoxus's 'Homocentric Spheres' model was not perfectly predictive, Aristotle adopted and *physicalized* it, turning the spheres into actual crystal spheres that formed the basis of his cosmology.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Eudoxus was antiquity's greatest problem-solver.
Problem 1: The planets move 'backwards' (retrograde). His solution: He built a complex celestial 'gearbox' (homocentric spheres), using the combined rotations of multiple spheres to mimic this strange dance.
Problem 2: Mathematicians found 'irrational numbers' like âˆš2, breaking all measurement. His solution: He invented a new set of rules (theory of proportions) that let you prove 'this rectangle' has the same ratio as 'that rectangle' without ever having to use a 'broken' number.

applications.text_en: The two most profound and important books of Euclid's 'Elements' (Book V - Proportions, and Book XII - Exhaustion) are considered to be based entirely on the work of Eudoxus.

impact.text_en: Eudoxus represents the second great leap in Greek mathematics after Pythagoras. He solved the crisis of irrational numbers, paving the way for rigorous proof, and he was the first to systematically apply mathematics as a tool to explain the physical world (planetary motion). Archimedes considered him one of the greatest mathematicians of antiquity.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Plato (whose philosophy emphasized mathematics as the way to understand cosmic order)
Hippasus of Metapontum (whose discovery of 'irrational numbers' created the core problem Eudoxus had to solve)

influenced.contribution_en: Aristotle (who adopted his 'Homocentric Spheres' as the basis for his physical cosmology)
Euclid (whose 'Elements' Book V and XII are compilations of Eudoxus's work)
Archimedes (who used Eudoxus's 'Method of Exhaustion' to calculate areas and volumes)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Eudoxus turned mathematics from a mystical study of numbers into a rigorous study of the 'continuum' (geometry and irrationals) and was the first to use it as the language of astronomy.

quiz.question_en: Eudoxus's 'Method of Exhaustion' was the precursor to which modern branch of mathematics?
quiz.explanation_en: The 'Method of Exhaustion' involved 'using up' the area of a curve (like a circle) by inscribing polygons with an infinite number of sides. This idea is the direct ancestor of the concept of 'limits' in modern integral calculus.
